Matt: Celia Kitzinger is one of my academic

icons.
She was the PhD supervisor of my old

supervisor, so maybe I feel there's a bit
of academic ancestry there. But I really

feel a lot of my thinking, my approach to
research, and even the methods I adopt

have been in part formed by her work. She
was one of the first to talk about

social constructionism in relation to
what was known as lesbian and gay

psychology in the 1980s, now more
commonly referred to as LGBT psychology

and was a leading developer of discourse
and conversation analytic approaches in

relation to the study of gender and
sexuality. But for me what sets it apart

is her staunch activism and commitment
to human rights.

Celia went to the High Court to get an
overseas marriage with her wife,

Professor Sue Wilkinson, legally
recognized, which finally came about with

the same-sex marriage act 2013. More
recently she co-founded the Coma and

Disorders of Consciousness Research
Center, after her sister Polly was

catastrophically brain injured in a car
accident, and this research in

collaboration with her sister Professor
Jenny Kitzinger focuses particularly on

the socio-legal issues surrounding the
treatment of people in

and minimally conscious states. I met
with Celia in July to discuss her work.

After pioneering a social
constructionist approach with her PhD

the social construction of lesbianism, I
was particularly interested in how she

now thinks about epistemology in
relation to her current research

interests. Celia: I think this place for just
not worrying about epistemology and

getting on with doing your interviews
and listening to what people are saying

and treating them not as true but as
good enough to be treated as true

because that's where what you've got
so I've done with Jenny I've done I

think it's close to 100 now interviews
with family members of people in

vegetative and minerally conscious
states saying tell tell me what happened

and they start with the cycling accident
or the stroke and they tell me what the

person looked like when they first saw
them in intensive care and they tell me

what happened when they were moved to
high dependency and they described the

eye-opening moment and they talk about
the awfulness of the lung infections and

their hope for recovery and their hope
gradually fading, they talk about the

nurses who cared and gave fantastic
loving care they talk about the nurses

who didn't care and they talk about the
physiotherapy and the splints to

straighten their limbs and the horror of
the tilt table which is like a sort of

crucifixion thing that you tilt somebody
up right on, they talk about the smart

testing they talk about whether they
agree or disagree with the doctor's

diagnosis. You know what, I'm not very
interested in whether right that's

essentialist or social constructionist, I
largely report it as this is what people

said, and frankly, I know people will
forgotten certain things and in moments

of high emotion have misunderstood or
misremembered others but here's what

here's what they experience, and I pretty,
we pretty much present that as evidence

of what families go through, and
the value of that is you take that data

to the medical profession and to the
lawyers and you say "This is what

families experience" okay so you didn't
know that families experience it this

way we're telling you.
And for sure they sometimes say, "I'm sure

it didn't happen that way because uh
because doctors wouldn't have done that

because" or "that doesn't make sense, that
medical procedure he's describing can't

have been done like that" yeah, okay, so
yeah that, not everything in interviews is

going to be right but there's enough, and
again it it's about cumulation of the

same things over and over, so this
accumulation of families saying for

example. "they they said he would be
disabled, but I had no idea what they

meant by that, I thought you'd been a
wheelchair or something this is not

disability, this is, this is devastation"
and we get versions of that in over and

over and over a we're in interviews that
doctors somehow are failing to

communicate to families in the early
days what the outcome of that kind of

brain injury will be. Well I'm really
frankly not very interested in whether

that's his social constructionist or you
know how that, the fact is if lots of

families say that to us and I take the
fact that lots of families say that to

us to doctors, doctors start thinking
"we're not explaining this very well, we

should try harder what would work better?"
How, how can we communicate to families

the level of devastation that this kind
of brain injury brings, without seeming

to, you know, terrify them and and and
make claims that can't be supported on

the one hand if the patient does
actually recover, but you know how do you

communicate that level of disability, and
that's a helpful discussion and that

actually moves things forward and that
helps families. So, stuff all the epistemo-

that's why I'm inpatient with, what
exactly is the epistemological status of

that data, its value is in communicating
to doctors you need to do this job

better. And, and it works to do that it
does work to do that so that's really

important, but, having said that so that's
the, I don't mind doing positivist

interviewing now it works. There's the
issue of how you translate what you find

in your data, into something that
communicates with people in a way that

an academic journal article doesn't.
So one of the things that I'm interested

in, and have worked with Jenny on, is
translating research findings, and they

are all qualitative actually, into
stories that can be told to audiences

who can engage with them at a different
kind of level, from from the academic

article or a summary of an academic
article, or an "easy read" version of an

academic article, or an academic talk, so
we've done puppet shows, shadow

puppets, so we got a puppet show person
to- these were actually from our

interviews, so our interviews were audio
recorded like this one is being, with permission to use the audio, and
to the sound of clips of audio, we have the

shadow puppets, we have Icarus falling
out of the sky and bumping his head

rather hard
we have Icarus being taken in an

ambulance that's what this is all
shadows a shadow ambulance

"doo-doo doo-doo" to a hospital, we have
Icarus in bed with a bandaged head we

have relatives visiting and leaning over
and the whole thing's takes 20 minutes

and it was a professional shadow artist
who created the show based on our

Matt: Based on the audio. Celia: based on our audio
recordings and our analysis of them so

we'd written the analysis of them
already of what sort of trajectory of

families is like, and then we had
permission for her to use some of the

audio so we selected out the audio to go

20-minute show which you sit in a

have a discussion period of up to an

families and practicing clinicians as

well, and it's a way of conveying, so I
think that's innovative

I think that's managing to convey
qualitative data in new ways. We've also

done the health talk thing which you
may have seen which is clips video clips

from our interviews, online, so families
can sit at home and look at them and we've

used those in training and education,
we've got sonnets, I don't know if you've
seen those? Matt: No. Celia: We commissioned a poet James Nash he's a quite well-known

northern poet, to write some sonnets for
us, and he's done three sonnets about

brain injury and recovery or death
following brain injury, which, which we

got some funding to set to music
so there's films of him reading them and

and set to music and, and sort of nice

and things, we've done, we've asked

doctors, social workers, lawyers
themselves, the patient, anyone, on

postcards, so we've got a postcard exhibition

just literally, just families written
postcards for things like you know "We

are her family listen to us, trust us, you
don't know her, we do" that sort of thing

Umm, yeah and Jenny's done this
radio program of between the ears which

is soundscapes associated with brain
injuries all of those are ways of taking

what we know about brain injury, which
comes directly from our research, and

translating it into forms of,
communicating, I don't know

the emotional truth of it and, the
the lived reality of it, yeah the lived

reality stuff discourses! The lived reality
of it in a way that people who are

making decisions either clinical or
judicial, can engage with in a different

kind of way. So I think that's where I
think the innovation is needed it's less

in arguing about the details of
particular research methods, and more in

thinking about if we want these, if we
want our findings to have an effect in

the world how do we communicate those to
people. Matt: With this adoption of creative

ways of communicating qualitative
research, I wondered whether Celia had

ever had trouble in having it recognized
as 'academic' However she explained to me

that with the university's emphasis on
'impact', she'd actually found quite the

opposite. Celia: One of the great,
amazingly wonderful things

my academic career is most of my career,
the political work that I did the policy

to related work that I did was
considered not part of my academic

existence it was in fact slightly grubby
hands, you know, my job was to produce

research and it was up to the rest of
the world to decide whether it was

interesting and whether they wanted to
use it for anything, but I was, it was

pure ivory tower stuff when I started so
the fact that I was involved in first in

lesbian and gay politics, and now in
policy change around brain injury has

just been, oh and same-sex marriage
stuff, when I was doing that the

university issued a statement saying
that they they understood that I was

involved in same-sex marriage act-, a
legal same-sex marriage case and that

they wished it to be known that "they did
not support it nor did they oppose it

they were entirely neutral". So it-
during my academic lifetime that has so

shifted from being, disreputable evening
a weekend stuff, we know you do it but

this is not part of your academic work,
towards it being impact, and something

you send off to the Ref, and obviously
I'm an impact case study for this

department, and that has been wholly
positive from my point of view it has

not changed what I do, at all, I still do
what I do, in the way that I want to do

it, the only way in which it has changed
what I do is think give me money to do

it so that kind of that kind of
encourages me and gives me more scope to

do what I want to do. so for me the
impact agenda has been wonderful

Matt: Often I think about the concept of impact as
being abstract and unobtainable, but I

was challenged by Celia, as impact just
seems to be a natural byproduct of her

work. I was interested in how Celia
demonstrates this impact. Celia: Basically we we

don't spend a lot of time capturing
impact it's more it's more that we spend

a lot of time doing the things that we
think will create change in the world in

the way that we think change needs to be
created and then we see the changes

happening like we get, like we give a talk
in a care home about

the fact that treatment best interest
decisions need to be made about feeding

tubes and this care home has never made a best
interest decision about a feeding tube

and then four weeks later they phone up
and say they've made some best

interest decisions and will we come and
talk to the families, so you know that or

we say that we think something called
Practice Direction 9E which is part of

the quarter protection practice
directions is wrong we write a

document that it's wrong we tell some
lawyers and solicitors and judges that

we think it's wrong, I got invited to
talk to do some continuing professional

development training with judges and
yesterday I was at a meeting at which

they were going to shall we shall we
abolish Practice Direction 9E, this

doesn't seem right, so you know I'll be
able to point to first there was

Practice Direction 9E which I thought
was wrong, I said it was wrong, and now

there isn't it isn't there anymore, so I
wasn't the only person who was saying it

was wrong, but I was one of them, and those
sorts of things make a difference, I mean the bigger

question is how do you make a difference
in the world ,and can you prove it was

just you, no you can't prove it was
just you, can you show cause and effect, I

pressed this button and this thing went
bing! Nope, but you can show that you were

part of how social change works in a
sociological sense which is multiple

different forces coming to bear on
trying to create a change. Matt: Over 20 years

ago Celia wrote a paper with an
undergraduate student using the story

completion method, which has influenced a
lot of qualitative researchers, including

myself, to use the method. You can hear
about how Celia has used story completion

for research around disorders of
consciousness below, and you can also

hear a short clip at the beginning of
the interview, but I was interested in

hearing generally what celia now thinks
about the story completion method.

I think it's a fun method, I'm actually amazed
that something I do with an

undergraduate student to satisfy an
intellectual itch basically, I was just

sort of scratching away at a question
what happens if you take data and you

don't interpret it the way that story
completion has regularly been used and

you do it a different way, it's amazing!
That something two decades ago with an

undergraduate should have been seen as
fundamental to a- and it was an old

method then, I'm a dying method then,
what is all this new excitement about
story completion? I'm slightly bemused!

Actually, to answer my own question,
I think partly it points to the poverty

of methods that we have as qualitative
researchers. Matt: Ok talk a bit about what do mean by poverty of methods.

Celia: Well there haven't been any radical new
innovative methods that I know of

actually when I was doing um Q
methodology for my PhD,

Personal Construct Theory was like "oh we're all
getting excited about Personal Construct Theory

that seems to completely died, I think
it's fundamentally unsatisfactory to

collect qualitative data, because there
are too many ways in which we know that

we're not getting it I don't know what
to call it

the truth about the world, and we know
we're not allowed to think that there's

a truth about the world either,
so we're uncertain about what we're

doing... We all know that none of the
methods that we use are perfect for

finding out what's happening in the
world let alone for putting the world to

rights, so I think we're all fairly
desperate to think perhaps this method

perhaps that method, that method, let's
find a new one, and I think I've been

around long enough to see people looking
for different new ones, and sometimes

finding old ones, and trying to reinvent
them to meet today's contingencies

and that's fine, but in the end it leaves me
thinking I'll just stick with, I'll just

stick with interviews!
Matt: Really? Because I- in my head

you're characterised by let's step away
from interviews. Celia: See I've been doing

nothing but interviews for the last
three years! Matt: But it's this this

return to, because the way you-
I suppose with disorders of

consciousness is sort of natural, but it
is it is almost giving voice...

Celia: Giving voice yes! Matt: but which is a-a
problematic, I mean you're not blindly

you're not kind of objectively giving
voice to people

but has your... Celia: They say I am, they
say, you know, that's fantastic you you're

bearing witness to what we're going
through, bearing witness and giving voice

are phrases that are quite often used and
I feel proud to hear that I am bearing

witness and giving voice and those are
phrases that I precisely used in that

article I did with Sue Wilkinson called
validating women's voices which was a

methodological critique of exactly that
perspective, so... Matt: so it's not a problematic

concept for you giving voice? Celia: It's
problematic in all sorts of ways, I want

people to have their own voices I don't
want to give somebody else a voice I

don't want that to be a world in which
that's necessary

not to mention the fact that if you
filter your voice through mine it's

gonna get distorted on the way out, to a
greater or lesser degree

I'm not epistemologically naive about
that and I know about the power dynamics

that are involved in attempting to
enable other people to speak through you

through one's own writing and speech,
it's one of the reasons I think that we

wanted to put the filmed interviews on a
website and as part of the purpose of

the shadow artistry, because that's
actually people's own voices

it's literally their breath coming out
and their sound, but even so we've

selected it we've shaped it we've
decided on the order as much, as you do

when you put quotes in an in a in an
article, although it is literally their

voice, it's you know, five minutes from a
two-hour interview, so yeah um, and we do

get a lot of pub- what you call it,
participant validation you go back to

the participant to say you know we've
y'know we had families with brain injuries on

all of our steering groups and advisory
panels and, and of course we are a family

with somebody with a brain injury
although our experience is not

everyone's experience, but these, these
arguments get rehearsed and rehearsed and rehearsed

these, these are concerns that can
paralyse you, you can, you can end up

just worrying about politics and theory
and epistemology and not do anything

because there isn't an answer, at least not one
I've found in 30 more, 30-plus years of

doing research, so... I've forgot what the question was
Matt: Well do people get bogged- because

you wrote about how you stopped using Q methodology
because people focused more on the method than

the topic. Celia: Yes Matt: So, do you think that uhh
yeah it can detract from the findings

when you use these... Celia: Yeah I mean
one of the nice things about interviews

is virtually everything that can be said
about interviews has been said, we're

running out arguments about them, so we have
very little discussion about our research

methodology now that we're
using interviews, whereas with with Q

methodology it was endless and tedious
with focus groups, see Jenny, Jenny used

to be a really big user of focus groups
and is quite well known for as a focus

group researcher, she's done a couple of
books on focus groups she was

instrumental in, she wrote a very famous
massively cited article on focus groups

for sensitive topics because people said
you couldn't do focus groups on

sensitive topics and she was researching
things that hiv/aids and child sexual

abuse and things with prisoners and she
was going yes you can, look... We're not

using focus groups, so we b- we both
actually have written an awful lot on

methodology, because we sort of
thought somehow somewhere there would be

the right way or a better way or a
valuable way of doing it, and I guess the

driving burning ambition now is how can
how... there is a problem with the world

these people's rights are being abused.
How can I find out

why that's happening and how can I
challenge it and put it right, and that

that overrides everything else and
actually just asking people tell me

what's happening, is... and hearing what
they say and treating it in a

non-ironical way
while bearing in mind that's just one

version... and reporting here's
what they say, it just seems like a

simple way of doing what I want to do
which is stop human rights abuses, of

these very vulnerable patients and their
families. Matt: So that's it! Hope our chat has

given you some things to think about and
I'm looking forward to seeing your
thoughts and comments.
